And enemies.] He proceeds in his description of their former misery : They were not only alienated from God as to outward condition, but were enemies by internal disagree— ment. Now they are called enemies as well in the active as in the passive signification of the term, i. e. they hated God as an enemy, they were hated by God as His euemies. This tends very much to augment the misery of the Colos- sians under that former condition: For if it be the height of felicity to be united to God through love 3 then is it the depth of misery to be separated from God by hostile en- mity.

That men in the state of a corrupt nature hate God, and therefore in this sense are his enemies, is plain from Rom. i. 30, where among other characteristics of the heathen, this is reckoned by the Apostle, that they are IzatersofGod.
